& = & -\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\triangledown F=0\end{matrix}</math></center> The vector <math>\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}</math> can be any vector tangent to the surface, and therefore <math>\triangledown F</math> must be proportional to the normal vector:<center><math> \hat{\mathbf{n}}=\frac{\triangledown F}{\left|\triangledown F\right|}.</math></center>
\paragraph{Metric of a curved surface}
A surface has been defined as an ensemble of points <math>\left\{ \mathbf{r}\left(u,v\right)\right\} </math> embedded in 3-dimensional space. In order to measure length along such a surface, we must integrate along a differential length element within it:<center><math>\begin{matrix} \mathrm{d}\mathbf{r} & = & \frac{\partial\mathbf{r}}{\partial u}\mathrm{d}u+\frac{\partial\mathbf{r}}{\partial v}\mathrm{d}v\equiv\mathbf{r}_{u}\mathrm{d}u+\mathbf{r}_{v}\mathrm{d}v,
\mathrm{d}s & = & \left|\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\right|,
\mathrm{d}s^{2} & = & \mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}=\left(\mathbf{r}_{u}\mathrm{d}u+\mathbf{r}_{v}\mathrm{d}v\right)\left(\mathbf{r}_{u}\mathrm{d}u+\mathbf{r}_{v}\mathrm{d}v\right)
& = & \overset{E}{\overbrace{\mathbf{r}_{u}^{2}}}\left(\mathrm{d}u\right)^{2}+2\overset{F}{\overbrace{\mathbf{r}_{u}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{v}}}\mathrm{d}u\mathrm{d}v+\overset{G}{\overbrace{\mathbf{r}_{v}^{2}}}\left(\mathrm{d}v\right)^{2}.\end{matrix}</math></center> The metric is defined as <center><math> g\equiv EG-F^{2}.</math></center> It is positive definite since<center><math> g=EG-F^{2}=\left(\mathbf{r}_{u}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{u}\right)\left(\mathbf{r}_{v}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{v}\right)-\left(\mathbf{r}_{u}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{v}\right)^{2}=\left(\mathbf{r}_{u}\times\mathbf{r}_{v}\right)^{2}>0.</math></center> The surface element can be expressed in terms of the metric:<center><math> \mathrm{d}A=\left|\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}_{u}\times\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}_{v}\right|=\left|\mathbf{r}_{u}\times\mathbf{r}_{v}\right|\mathrm{d}u\mathrm{d}v=\sqrt{g}\mathrm{d}u\mathrm{d}v.</math></center> We illustrate this in the Monge representation as an example. Here,<center><math>\begin{matrix} \mathbf{r}_{u} & = & \mathbf{r}_{x}=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(x,y,h\left(x,y\right)\right)
& = & \left(1,0,h_{x}\right),
\mathbf{r}_{v} & = & \mathbf{r}_{y}=\left(0,1,h_{y}\right).\end{matrix}</math></center> The surface element is<center><math> \mathrm{d}A=\sqrt{g}\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y,</math></center> with the metric<center><math>\begin{matrix} g & = & \left(\mathbf{r}_{u}\times\mathbf{r}_{v}\right)^{2}=\left|\begin{matrix}{ccc} \mathbf{\hat{x}} & \mathbf{\hat{y}} & \mathbf{\hat{z}}
1 & 0 & h_{x}
0 & 1 & h_{y}\end{matrix}\right|,\\ \sqrt{g} & = & \sqrt{1+h_{x}^{2}+h_{y}^{2}}.\end{matrix}</math></center> The length element is<center><math>\begin{matrix} \mathrm{d}s^{2} & = & r_{x}^{2}\mathrm{d}x^{2}+2\mathbf{r}_{x}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{y}\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y+r_{y}^{2}\mathrm{d}y^{2},
\mathrm{d}s & = & \sqrt{\left(1+h_{x}\right)^{2}\mathrm{d}x^{2}+\left(1+h_{y}\right)^{2}\mathrm{d}y^{2}}.\end{matrix}</math></center> and therefore we have in the Monge representation<center><math> \mathrm{d}s=\sqrt{\left(1+h_{x}\right)^{2}\mathrm{d}x^{2}+\left(1+h_{y}\right)^{2}\mathrm{d}y^{2}},</math></center> <center><math> \mathrm{d}A=\sqrt{1+h_{x}^{2}+h_{y}^{2}}\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y.</math></center> In the implicit representation, one can begin the same process by writing the surface element in terms of the volume element:<center><math> \mathrm{d}A=\delta^{\left(3\right)}\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}_{s}\left(x,y,z\right)\right)\mathrm{d}^{3}r,</math></center> using the 3D Dirac delta function <math>\delta^{\left(3\right)}\left(\mathbf{r}\right)</math>. A general property of the Dirac delta is that <center><math> \delta\left(f\left(x\right)-a\right)=\frac{\delta\left(x-f^{-1}\left(a\right)\right)}{\left.\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}\right|_{x=f^{-1}\left(a\right)}},</math></center> where <math>f^{-1}</math> is the inverse function such that <math>f\left(x\right)=a\Rightarrow f^{-1}\left(a\right)=x</math>. In terms of the function <math>F</math> such that the surface is defined by $F=0$, we can use this property to write<center><math> \delta^{\left(3\right)}\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}_{s}\left(F\right)\right)=\delta\left(F\right)\left|\triangledown F\right|,</math></center> or<center><math> \mathrm{d}A=\delta\left(F\right)\left|\triangledown F\right|\mathrm{d}^{3}r.</math></center> Returning to the implicit version of the Monge representation,<center><math>\begin{matrix} \triangledown F & = & \left(-h_{x},-h_{y},1\right),
\left|\triangledown F\right| & = & \sqrt{1+h_{x}^{2}+h_{y}^{2}},\end{matrix}</math></center> <center><math> \mathrm{d}A=\delta\left(z-h\left(x,y\right)\right)\mathrm{d}z\sqrt{1+h_{x}^{2}+h_{y}^{2}}\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y.</math></center>
\paragraph{Curvature of surfaces}
So far we have discussed first order differential expressions and the area element. This has to do with properties like surface energy <math>\mathrm{d}f=\sigma\mathrm{d}A</math>. Curvature is a second order property, useful in discussing deformations and fluctuations. Consider a curve <math>\mathbf{r}\left(s\right)</math> with <math>0<s<L</math> on a surface parametrized by <math>u</math> and <math>v</math>. On the curve, <math>u=u\left(s\right)</math> and <math>v=v\left(s\right)</math>. If <math>\hat{\mathbf{n}}</math> is a vector normal to the surface, the local curvature (of the curve) is<center><math> \kappa=\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}\mathbf{r}\left(s\right)}{\mathrm{d}s^{2}}\cdot\hat{n}=\mathbf{r}^{\prime\prime}\left(s\right)\cdot\hat{\mathbf{n}}.</math></center> The first derivative is<center><math> \frac{\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}{\mathrm{d}s}=\frac{\partial\mathbf{r}}{\partial u}\frac{\mathrm{d}u}{\mathrm{d}s}+\frac{\partial\mathbf{r}}{\partial v}\frac{\mathrm{d}v}{\mathrm{d}s}=\mathbf{r}_{u}u^{\prime}+\mathbf{r}_{v}v^{\prime},</math></center> and the second derivative<center><math>\begin{matrix} \frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}\mathbf{r}}{\mathrm{d}s^{2}} & = & \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{u}u^{\prime}+\mathbf{r}_{v}v^{\prime}\right)
& = & \mathbf{r}_{uu}\left(u^{\prime}\right)^{2}+\mathbf{r}_{vv}\left(v^{\prime}\right)^{2}+2\mathbf{r}_{uv}u^{\prime}v^{\prime}+\mathbf{r}_{u}u^{\prime\prime}+\mathbf{r}_{v}v^{\prime\prime}.\end{matrix}</math></center> Since <math>\hat{\mathbf{n}}</math> is perpendicular to <math>\mathbf{r}_{u}</math> and $\mathbf{r}_{v}$, we are left with<center><math> \kappa=L\left(u^{\prime}\right)^{2}+N\left(v^{\prime}\right)^{2}+2Mu^{\prime}v^{\prime},</math></center> <center><math>\begin{matrix} L & = & \hat{\mathbf{n}}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{uu},
N & = & \hat{\mathbf{n}}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{vv},
M & = & \hat{\mathbf{n}}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{uv}.\end{matrix}</math></center>
\begin{minipage}[t]{1\columnwidth} \begin{shaded} (some missing formulas...)\end{shaded} \end{minipage}<center><math>\begin{matrix} L & = & -\hat{\mathbf{n}}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{u},
N & = & -\hat{\mathbf{n}}_{v}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{v},
M & = & -\hat{\mathbf{n}}_{v}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{u}=-\hat{\mathbf{n}}_{u}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{v}.\end{matrix}</math></center> We finally obtain<center><math> \kappa=\frac{\left(\mathbf{\hat{n}}_{u}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{u}\right)\mathrm{d}u^{2}+\left(\mathbf{\hat{n}}_{v}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{u}+\mathbf{\hat{n}}_{u}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{v}\right)\mathrm{d}u\mathrm{d}v+\left(\hat{\mathbf{n}}_{v}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{v}\right)\mathrm{d}v^{2}}{\left(\mathrm{d}s\right)^{2}},</math></center> and with <math>\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}=\mathbf{r}_{u}\mathrm{d}u+\mathbf{r}_{v}\mathrm{d}v</math> and $\mathrm{d}\hat{\mathbf{n}}=\hat{\mathbf{n}}_{u}\mathrm{d}u+\hat{\mathbf{n}}_{v}\mathrm{d}v$,<center><math> \kappa=-\frac{\mathrm{d\hat{\mathbf{n}}\cdot}\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}{\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}=-\frac{\mathrm{d\hat{\mathbf{n}}\cdot}\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}{\mathrm{d}s^{2}}.</math></center> (missing diagram...)
\paragraph{Curvature tensor}
Since $\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\mathbf{\hat{n}}=0$,<center><math> \hat{\mathbf{n}}+\mathrm{d}\hat{\mathbf{n}}=\hat{\mathbf{n}}\left(\mathbf{r}+\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\right)=\mathbf{\hat{n}\left(\mathbf{r}\right)}+\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\triangledown\mathbf{\hat{n}},</math></center> or <center><math> \mathrm{d}\mathbf{\hat{n}}=\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\triangledown\hat{\mathbf{n}}\equiv\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\overleftrightarrow{Q}.</math></center> The quantity <center><math>\begin{matrix} \overleftrightarrow{Q} & = & \triangledown\hat{\mathbf{n}},
Q_{ij} & = & \left(\triangledown\hat{\mathbf{n}}\right)_{ij}=\frac{\partial}{\partial r_{i}}\left(\mathbf{\hat{n}}\right)_{j},\end{matrix}</math></center> is a second rank tensor or dyadic.
Now, we can write <math>\kappa</math> with \begin{minipage}[t]{1\columnwidth} \begin{shaded} (some missing formulas...)\end{shaded} \end{minipage}<center><math> \kappa=-\frac{\mathrm{d\hat{\mathbf{n}}\cdot}\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}{\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}=-\frac{\mathrm{\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\overleftrightarrow{Q}\cdot}\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}{\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}=-\frac{\mathrm{\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\overleftrightarrow{Q}\cdot}\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}{\mathrm{d}s^{2}},</math></center> or<center><math> \kappa=\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\left(s\right)\cdot\overleftrightarrow{Q}\cdot\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\left(s\right)=\sum_{ij}r_{i}^{\prime}Q_{ij}r_{j}^{\prime}</math></center> where <math>\mathbf{r}'(s)={\normalcolor \frac{\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}{\mathrm{d}s}}</math>.
This can be used for the case of an implicitly defined surface where $\hat{\mathbf{n}}=\frac{\triangledown F}{\left|\triangledown F\right|}$:<center><math>\begin{matrix} Q_{ij} & = & \left[\triangledown\left(\frac{\triangledown F}{\left|\triangledown F\right|}\right)\right]_{ij}
& = & \partial_{i}\left(\frac{\partial_{j}F}{\left|\triangledown F\right|}\right)=\frac{\partial_{i}\partial_{j}F}{\left|\triangledown F\right|}-\left(\partial_{j}F\right)\cdot\frac{\partial_{i}F}{\left|\triangledown F\right|}.\end{matrix}</math></center> Using $\partial_{i}\left|\triangledown F\right|=\partial_{i}\sqrt{\left(\partial_{x}F\right)^{2}+\left(\partial_{y}F\right)^{2}+\left(\partial_{z}F\right)^{2}}$,<center><math> Q_{ij}=-\frac{1}{\left|\triangledown F\right|}\left[\frac{\partial_{i}\left|\triangledown F\right|\partial_{j}F}{\left|\triangledown F\right|}-\partial_{i}\partial_{j}F\right].</math></center>
06/16/2009
\paragraph{The curvature tensor and its invariants}
The dyadic matrix <math>Q=\overleftrightarrow{Q}</math> has eigenvalues <math>\lambda_{i}</math>, a trace <math>\mathrm{Tr}Q=\sum_{i}\lambda_{i}</math> and a determinant <math>\mathrm{Det}Q=\left|Q\right|=\prod_{i}\lambda_{i}</math> which are invariant under similarity transformations <math>\tilde{Q}=UQU^{-1}</math>. The sum of the principal minors <math>\sum_{i}M_{ii}</math> is also invariant: to see this, consider the characteristic polynomial<center><math>\begin{matrix} P\left(\lambda\right) & = & \mathrm{Det}\left(Q-\lambda I\right)
& = & \mathrm{Det}\left(U^{-1}U\right)\mathrm{Det}\left(Q-\lambda I\right)
& & \mathrm{Det}\left(U^{-1}\right)\mathrm{Det}\left(Q-\lambda I\right)\mathrm{Det}\left(U\right)
& = & \mathrm{Det}\left(U^{-1}QU-\lambda U^{-1}IU\right)
& = & \mathrm{Det}\left(\tilde{Q}-\lambda I\right).\end{matrix}</math></center> Here <math>I</math> is the unit matrix. Expanding <math>P\left(\lambda\right)</math> in powers of $\lambda$,<center><math> P\left(\lambda\right)=\left|Q\right|-\lambda\sum_{i}M_{ii}+\lambda^{2}\sum_{i}Q_{ii}-\lambda^{3}.</math></center> We can identify clearly the coefficients of the polynomial <math>P(\lambda)</math>as the 3 invariants. One eigenvalue is always equal to zero (as an exercise do it in the implicit representation). If we choose <math>\lambda_{3}=0</math>, we are reduced to two nontrivial invariants: <math>\mathrm{Tr}Q=\lambda_{1}+\lambda_{2}</math> and <math>\sum_{i}M_{ii}=\lambda_{1}\lambda_{2}</math>(as <math>{\normalcolor \mathrm{Det}}(Q)=0)</math>. These invariants are called the ''mean curvature'' <math>H</math> and the ''Gaussian curvature'' $K$:<center><math> H\equiv\frac{1}{2}\left(\lambda_{1}+\lambda_{2}\right),</math></center> <center><math> K\equiv\lambda_{1}\lambda_{2}.</math></center>
For example, in the implicit representation we can write<center><math>\begin{matrix} \mathbf{\hat{n}} & = & \frac{\triangledown F}{\left|\triangledown F\right|},
N & \equiv & \left|\triangledown F\right|,
\mathrm{Tr}Q & = & -\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}\left[\frac{N_{i}F_{i}}{N}-F_{ii}\right],\end{matrix}</math></center> where <center><math> \begin{cases} N_{i}=\frac{\partial}{\partial r_{i}}N,
F_{ij}=\frac{\partial}{\partial r_{i}}\frac{\partial}{\partial r_{j}}F.\end{cases}</math></center> Note that since, for instance, <center><math> N_{i}=\partial_{i}\sqrt{F_{x}^{2}+F_{y}^{2}+F_{z}^{2}}=\frac{\partial_{i}\left(F_{j}F_{j}\right)}{2\sqrt{F_{x}^{2}+F_{y}^{2}+F_{z}^{2}}}=\frac{1}{N}F_{j}F_{ij},</math></center> with a few more steps we can show (another exercise) that<center><math> H=-\frac{1}{2N^{3}}\left[2F_{x}F_{y}F_{xy}-F_{xx}\left(F_{y}^{2}+F_{z}^{2}\right)+\mathrm{2\, cyclic\, permuations}\right],</math></center> <center><math> K=-\frac{1}{2N^{3}}\left[F_{xx}F_{yy}F_{z}^{2}-F_{xy}^{2}F_{z}^{2}+2F_{xz}F_{x}\left(F_{y}F_{yz}-F_{z}F_{yy}\right)+\mathrm{2\, cyclic\, permuations}\right],</math></center>
where by cyclic permutations we mean permuting the axes: <math>x\rightarrow y\rightarrow z\rightarrow x</math>. In the case of the Monge representation where <math>F=z-h\left(x,y\right)</math>, <math>H</math> and <math>K</math> have a simpler form: <center><math>\begin{matrix} N & = & \sqrt{1+h_{x}^{2}+h_{y}^{2}},
h_{i} & = & \partial_{i}h,
F_{x} & = & -h_{x},
F_{y} & = & -h_{y},
F_{z} & = & 1.\end{matrix}</math></center> One can then show that<center><math> H=\frac{1}{2\left(\sqrt{1+h_{x}^{2}+h_{y}^{2}}\right)^{3}}\left[\left(1+h_{y}^{2}\right)h_{xx}+\left(1+h_{x}^{2}\right)h_{yy}-2h_{x}h_{y}h_{z}\right],</math></center> <center><math> K=\frac{h_{xx}h_{yy}-h_{xy}^{2}}{\left(1+h_{x}^{2}+h_{y}^{2}\right)^{2}}.</math></center> ====Small disturbances of planar surfaces==== To treat nearly flat surfaces, one can use the Monge representation to expand a Taylor series around a completely flat surface in derivatives of $h\left(x,y\right)$:<center><math>\begin{matrix} N & = & \sqrt{1+h_{x}^{2}+h_{y}^{2}}\simeq1+\frac{1}{2}\left(h_{x}^{2}+h_{y}^{2}\right),\end{matrix}</math></center> or equivalently<center><math> N=\left|\triangledown F\right|\simeq1+\frac{1}{2}\left(\triangledown_{||}h\right)^{2}.</math></center> From similar arguments, one can show that<center><math>\begin{matrix} H & \simeq & \frac{1}{2}\left(h_{xx}+h_{yy}\right)=\frac{1}{2}\triangledown_{\parallel}^{2}h,
K & \simeq & h_{xx}h_{yy}-\left(h_{xy}\right)^{2}.\end{matrix}</math></center> In the general parametric representation,<center><math> \kappa=\frac{L\left(du\right)^{2}+2Mdudv+N\left(dv\right)^{2}}{E\left(du\right)^{2}+2Fdudv+G\left(dv\right)^{2}}</math></center> with <math>L=\hat{\mathbf{n}}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{uu}</math><math>M=\hat{\mathbf{n}}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{uv}</math>and <math>N=\hat{\mathbf{n}}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{vv}</math>. Picking a unit vector <math>\hat{\mathbf{a}}=l\mathbf{r}_{u}+m\mathbf{r}_{v}</math> in the plane, the curvature in the direction of <math>\hat{\mathbf{a}}</math> is given by<center><math> \kappa=Ll^{2}+2Mlm+Nm^{2}.</math></center> The parameters $l$ and $m$ must obey<center><math> a=\hat{|\mathbf{a}}|=1\Rightarrow\hat{\mathbf{a}}\cdot\hat{\mathbf{a}}=El^{2}+2Fml+Gm^{2}=1.</math></center> In investigating <math>\kappa\left(l,m\right)</math> as a function of the direction of <math>\hat{\mathbf{a}}</math>, we can find its extrema with the constraint $a=1$ by adding a Lagrange multiplier:<center><math>\begin{matrix} \tilde{\kappa} & = & \kappa\left(l,m\right)-\lambda(El_{2}+2Flm+Nm^{2}),
& \Downarrow
\frac{\partial\tilde{\kappa}}{\partial l}=\frac{\partial\tilde{\kappa}}{\partial m} & = & 0.\end{matrix}</math></center> The solution takes the form of a quadratic equation<center><math> \kappa^{2}\left(EG-F^{2}\right)-\kappa\left(EN+GL-2FM\right)+\left(LN-M^{2}\right)=0,</math></center> which has 2 roots: <math>\kappa_{a}</math> and <math>\kappa_{b}.</math> This extremum finding process defines the ''principal directions'' , which (we will state without proof) are always perpendicular to each other. The two invariants are then<center><math>\begin{matrix} H & = & \frac{1}{2}\left(\kappa_{a}+\kappa_{b}\right)=-\frac{EN+GL-2FM}{2\left(EG-F^{2}\right)},
K & = & \kappa_{a}\kappa_{b}=\frac{LN-M^{2}}{EG-F^{2}}.\end{matrix}</math></center>
Consider a few cases in terms of the radii of curvature <math>r_{a}=\frac{1}{\kappa_{a}}</math> and <math>r_{b}=\frac{1}{\kappa_{b}}</math>:
#If at some point both radii are positive, then <math>\kappa_{a}</math>, <math>\kappa_{b}</math>, <math>H</math> and <math>K</math> are all positive. The surface is convex around the point, as in (17a). #If both are negative, then <math>H<0</math> and <math>K>0</math>. The surface is concave around the point, as in (17b). #If the two have opposing signs, <math>K</math> is negative and one is at a saddle point of the surface, as in (17c). #The special surface having <math>H=(\kappa_{a}+\kappa_{b})/2=0</math> at ''any'' point is called a ''minimal surface'' (or ''Schwartz surface,'' after the 19th century mathematician who studied them in detail). These surfaces have a saddle at every point, as one curvature is always positive and the second negative: <math>\kappa_{a}=-\kappa_{b}</math>. Hence, their Gaussian curvature is always negative: <math>K<0.</math> We will use the principal directions to describe a local paraboloid expansion of a nearly flat surface. In general,<center><math> z=z_{0}+\frac{1}{2}L\left(u-u_{0}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2}N\left(v-v_{0}\right)^{2}.</math></center> In the Monge representation,<center><math> z=z_{0}+\frac{1}{2}\kappa_{a}\left(x-x_{0}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\kappa_{b}\left(y-y_{0}\right)^{2}.</math></center> ====Free energy of soft surfaces==== \begin{description}
[{Book:}] Landau & Lifshitz' book on ''Elasticity '' has a chapter on elasticity of hard (solid) shells. There is also a book by Boal on ''elasticity and mechanics of fluid membranes'' . Safran's book shows how the parameters we describe can be derived from a microscopic model where the lipid (surfactant) molecules are modeled as beads connected with various springs. \end{description} Consider a liquid surface or fluid membrane: as such a surface curves, its free energy varies. Phenomenologically,<center><math> \Delta F=\sigma\int\mathrm{d}A+2k\int\left(H-C_{0}\right)^{2}\mathrm{d}A+\bar{k}\int K\mathrm{d}A.</math></center> All the integrals are taken over the surface. The fact that the above expression models a fluid membrane is related to the fact that we do not account for any lateral shear forces. Molecules composing the fluid membrane are free to flow inside the membrane but they resist elastic deformations such as bending. The first term describes the contribution of surface tension, which is proportional to the total surface area. The geometric values <math>H</math> and <math>K</math> are the mean and Gaussian curvatures we have already encountered. The coefficients <math>k</math> and <math>\bar{k}</math> (with units of energy) depend, like <math>\sigma</math>, on the material properties in question. The spontaneous curvature <math>C_{0}</math> is also a material property: it defines a certain preferred angle (perhaps due to the shape of surfactant molecules), and its sign depends on the preferred direction of curvature. See (18) for an illustration. Unless there is an active process that causes an asymmetry in the lipid composition of the two leaflets, the bilayer will have the same lipid composition on the inside and outside, and therefore has in total <math>C_{0}=0</math>. Usually for fluid membranes, <math>k</math> and <math>\bar{k}</math> range from <math>\sim1k_{B}T</math> to <math>\sim40k_{B}T</math>.
One example is a sphere of radius $R$, where:<center><math>\begin{matrix} H & = & \frac{1}{2}\left(R_{1}^{-1}+R_{2}^{-1}\right)=R^{-1},
K & = & R^{-2}.\end{matrix}</math></center> This gives<center><math>\begin{matrix} \left.\Delta F\right|_{\mathrm{sphere}} & = & \sigma\int\mathrm{d}A+2k\int\left(H-C_{0}\right)^{2}\mathrm{d}A+\bar{k}\int K\mathrm{d}A
& = & 4\pi R^{2}\sigma+2k\left(\frac{1}{R}-C_{0}\right)^{2}\cdot4\pi R^{2}+4\pi\bar{k}
& = & 4\pi R^{2}\sigma+8\pi k\left(1-C_{0}R\right)^{2}+4\pi\bar{k}.\end{matrix}</math></center> The interesting fact that the surface integral over the Gaussian curvature <math>K</math> gives a constant value of <math>4\pi</math> - independent on the radius <math>R</math> of the sphere - has a deep meaning. It is related to the famous Gauss-Bonnet theorem which will be stated here without further details: according to this theorem, the integral over the Gaussian curvature is a topological invariant of the surface whose value is equal to <math>4\pi\left(1-g\right)</math>, where <math>g</math> is the ''genus'' of the surface. A sphere or any closed object with no {}"holes" has <math>g=0</math> and an integrated Gaussian curvature of <math>4\pi</math>, while a torus (or {}"donut") with one hole has <math>g=1</math> and hence a zero integrated Gaussian curvature. {{Sidenote|More information about the Gauss-Bonnet theorem may be found in books on differential geometry}}
A second example is an infinite cylinder with radius <math>R</math>. Here, <math>\kappa_{a}=\frac{1}{R}</math> and $\kappa_{b}=0$. The free energy per unit length is<center><math>\begin{matrix} \frac{\Delta F}{L} & = & 2\pi R\sigma+2k\left(\frac{1}{2R}-C_{0}\right)\cdot2\pi R+\bar{k}\overset{{\scriptstyle =0}}{\overbrace{\int\frac{1}{R}\cdot0\cdot\mathrm{d}A}}
& = & 2\pi R\sigma+\frac{4\pi k}{R}\left(\frac{1}{2}-C_{0}R\right)^{2}.\end{matrix}</math></center> An even simpler example is the infinite plane, where <math>\kappa_{a}=\kappa_{b}=0\Rightarrow K=H=0</math>. This yields<center><math> \frac{\Delta F}{\mathrm{Area}}=\sigma+2kC_{0}^{2}.</math></center>
06/18/2009
====Thermal fluctuations of a plane==== \begin{description}
[{Book:}] Safran's book. \end{description} To second order in derivatives of <math>h</math> in the Monge representation for $\bar{k}=0$,<center><math> \Delta F=\frac{\sigma}{2}\int\left(\triangledown h\right)^{2}\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y+\frac{2k}{4}\left(\triangledown^{2}h\right)^{2}\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y.</math></center> The minimum of energy is obtained for a flat surface. Going to a Fourier transformed form, we have<center><math>\begin{matrix} h_{\mathbf{q}} & = & \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\right)^{2}\int\mathrm{d}^{2}r\, h\left(\mathbf{r}\right)e^{-i\mathbf{q}\cdot\mathbf{r}},
h\left(\mathbf{r}\right) & = & \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\right)^{2}\int\mathrm{d}^{2}q\, h_{\mathbf{q}}e^{i\mathbf{q}\cdot\mathbf{r}},
\left(\triangledown^{2}h\right)^{2} & \rightarrow & q^{4}h_{\mathbf{q}}h_{-\mathbf{q}},
\left(\triangledown h\right)^{2} & \rightarrow & q^{2}h_{\mathbf{q}}h_{-\mathbf{q}}.\end{matrix}</math></center> This gives for the free energy in terms of the normal surface modes $\left\{ h_{q}\right\} $:<center><math> \Delta F=\frac{\sigma}{2}\int\left(q_{x}^{2}+q_{y}^{2}\right)h_{\mathbf{q}}h_{-\mathbf{q}}\mathrm{d}^{2}q+\frac{k}{2}\int\left(q_{x}^{2}+q_{y}^{2}\right)^{2}h_{\mathbf{q}}h_{-\mathbf{q}}\mathrm{d}^{2}q.</math></center> With <math>h\left(\mathbf{r}\right)</math> real, we know that <math>h_{\mathbf{q}}=h_{-\mathbf{q}}^{*}</math>, or <math>h_{\mathbf{q}}h_{-\mathbf{q}}=\left|h_{\mathbf{q}}\right|^{2}</math>. From the classical equipartition theorem we can estimate the equilibrium energy for the average of this quantity:<center><math>\begin{matrix} \frac{k_{B}T}{2} & = & \frac{1}{2}\sigma q^{2}\left\langle h_{\mathbf{q}}h_{-\mathbf{q}}\right\rangle +\frac{1}{2}kq^{4}\left\langle h_{\mathbf{q}}h_{-\mathbf{q}}\right\rangle
& \Downarrow
\left\langle \left|h_{\mathbf{q}}\right|^{2}\right\rangle & = & \frac{k_{B}T}{\sigma q^{2}+kq^{4}}.\end{matrix}</math></center> It is now useful to define the new length scale <math>\xi\equiv\sqrt{\frac{k}{\sigma}}</math>, and examine the limits of <math>k\xi\gg1</math> and <math>k\xi\ll1</math>. In the <math>k\xi\ll1</math> limit, one obtains a surface dominated by surface tension. Consider the real space thermal correlation function<center><math>\begin{matrix} \left\langle h\left(\mathbf{r}\right)h\left(\mathbf{r}\right)\right\rangle & = & \frac{1}{\left(2\pi\right)^{2}}\int\int e^{-i\mathbf{q}\cdot\mathbf{r}}e^{-i\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\cdot\mathbf{r}}\overset{{\scriptstyle =2\pi\delta\left(\mathbf{q}+\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)}}{\overbrace{\left\langle h_{\mathbf{q}}h_{\mathbf{q^{\prime}}}\right\rangle }}\mathrm{d}^{2}q\mathrm{d}^{2}q^{\prime}
& = & \frac{1}{2\pi}\int\mathrm{d}^{2}q\,\frac{k_{B}T}{\sigma q^{2}}.\end{matrix}</math></center> Since this integral diverges at both large and small <math>q</math>, to obtain a physically meaningful result we must introduce cutoffs to the range of <math>\mathit{q}</math>: <math>q_{\mathrm{min}}=\frac{2\pi}{L}</math> where <math>L</math> is the linear dimension of the system, and <math>q_{\mathrm{max}}=\frac{2\pi}{a}</math> where <math>a\sim3\AA</math> is the typical molecular size. This gives an example of a famous result from the 1930's, known as Landau-Peierls instability for 2-dimensional systems and the lack of an ordered phase at $T>0$:<center><math> \left\langle h^{2}\left(\mathbf{r}\right)\right\rangle =\frac{k_{B}T}{2\pi\sigma}\ln\frac{L}{a}.</math></center> Since the logarithmic divergence is very weak, it turns out that the thermal fluctuations are two or three Angstroms in size for a water surface of macroscopic (a few millimeters or centimeters) dimension. These thermal fluctuations are not easy to measure because the signal should come only from the water molecules at the water surface. In the 1980s they were measured for the first time for water surfaces at room temperature using a powerful synchrotron X-ray source. The technique employs scattering at very low angles (called grazing incidence) from the water surface and obtains the intensity of the scattered X-ray as function of <math>q.</math> This quantity is proportional to <math>\langle|h_{q}|^{2}\rangle</math>. In the opposite limit where <math>k\xi\gg1</math>, the membrane is dominated by its elastic energy, and $\sigma\ll kq^{2}$ can be neglected: <center><math> \left\langle \left|h_{\mathbf{q}}\right|^{2}\right\rangle =\frac{k_{B}T}{\sigma q^{2}+kq^{4}}\simeq\frac{k_{B}T}{kq^{4}}\sim q^{-4}.</math></center> The divergence at small <math>q</math> is much larger here than in the first case, and<center><math>\begin{matrix} \left\langle h^{2}\right\rangle & = & \frac{k_{B}T}{2\pi k}\int_{q_{\mathrm{min}}}^{q_{\mathrm{max}}}\frac{1}{q^{3}}\mathrm{d}q
& = & \frac{k_{B}T}{4\pi k}\left[-\overset{\approx0}{\overbrace{\left(\frac{1}{q_{\mathrm{max}}}\right)^{2}}}+\left(\frac{1}{q_{\mathrm{min}}}\right)^{2}\right],\end{matrix}</math></center> and <center><math>\begin{matrix} \left\langle h^{2}\right\rangle & = & \frac{k_{B}T}{2\left(2\pi\right)^{2}}\frac{L^{2}}{k}
& \Downarrow
\sqrt{\left\langle h^{2}\right\rangle } & \sim & L.\end{matrix}</math></center> In such membranes, which are dominated by elasticity, the fluctuations increase linearly with membrane size. For a membrane around <math>1\mathrm{cm}</math> in length, a typical amplitude is in the <math>\mu\mathrm{m}</math> range. Another interesting observation is that <math>\left\langle h^{2}\right\rangle \sim T/k</math>. For small <math>k</math> (flexible membranes), as well as for higher temperatures, the fluctuations become larger. This is valid as long as the condition of the elastic-dominated case, <math>\sigma\ll kq^{2}</math>, remains satisfied. Also, recall that the source of the large membrane fluctuations comes from the small <math>q</math> or large wavelengths, and not from small wiggles associated with the motion of individual molecules. ====Rayleigh instability==== Due to surface tension, a cylinder of liquid created in air (or surrounded by another immiscible liquid) is unstable and will break into spherical droplets. Let's consider the following model: a cylinder of length <math>L</math> and smaller radius <math>R_{0}\ll L</math>, which contains inside it an ''incompressible'' liquid with a total volume of <math>V=\pi LR_{0}^{2}</math>. For simplicity, we will consider perturbations which preserve the body-of-revolution symmetry around the main axis and the cylinder length <math>L</math>, such that only the local radius <math>\rho\left(z\right)</math> along the cylinder's axis may vary. Expanding <math>\rho</math> in normal modes then gives<center><math> \rho\left(z\right)=R+\sum_{q\neq0}\rho_{q}e^{iqz}.</math></center> The mode amplitudes are <math>\rho_{q}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{L}}\int\rho\left(z\right)e^{-iqz}\mathrm{d}z</math>. Note that <center><math> \left\langle \rho\left(z\right)\right\rangle =\frac{1}{L}\int_{0}^{L}\rho\left(z\right)\mathrm{d}z=R,</math></center> with <math>R</math> depending on <math>R_{0}</math>. This dependence can be found from the constant volume constraint<center><math>\begin{array}{lcl} V & = & \pi R_{0}^{2}L=\int_{0}^{L}\pi\rho^{2}\left(z\right)\mathrm{d}z \\
& = & \pi R^{2}L+\frac{\pi}{L}\sum_{q}\sum_{q^{\prime}}\overset{{\scriptstyle =L\delta_{qq^{\prime}}}}{\overbrace{\left(\int e^{i(q+q^{\prime})z}\mathrm{d}z\right)}}\rho_{q}\rho_{-q} \\
& \Downarrow & \\
R^{2}L & = & R_{0}^{2}L-\sum_{q\ne0}\rho_{q}\rho_{-q}.\end{array}</math></center> This is exact, but for small perturbations we can expand the root and obtain<center><math> R\simeq R_{0}\left(1-\frac{1}{2L}\sum_{q\ne0}\left|\rho_{q}\right|^{2}\right).</math></center> The surface energy of the distorted cylinder will be<center><math> F_{s}=\sigma\cdot\mathrm{Area}=\sigma\cdot\int_{0}^{L}2\pi\rho\left(z\right)\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{\partial\rho}{\partial z}\right)^{2}}\mathrm{d}z.</math></center> (We have used expression for the surface area of a body-of-revolution with axial symmetry). Expanding all quantities up to second order in <math>\rho_{q}</math> gives<center><math> \begin{array}{lcl} F_{s} & \simeq & \overset{{\scriptstyle =0}}{\overbrace{2\pi\sigma\int_{0}^{L}\left(\rho\left(z\right)-R\right)\mathrm{d}z}}+2\pi\sigma\int_{0}^{L}\mathrm{d}zR\left(1+\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\partial\rho}{\partial r}\right)^{2}\right) \\ & = & 2\pi\sigma L\left(R_{0}-\frac{R_{0}}{2L}\sum_{q}\frac{\left|\rho_{q}\right|^{2}}{R_{0}^{2}}\right)+\frac{\pi\sigma R_{0}}{L}\int_{0}^{L}\sum_{q}\sum_{q^{\prime}}\left(-q\cdot q^{\prime}\right)e^{i\left(q+q^{\prime}\right)z}\mathrm{d}z \\
& = & 2\pi\sigma LR_{0}-2\pi\sigma R_{0}\sum_{q}\frac{\left|\rho_{q}\right|^{2}}{2R_{0}^{2}}+2\pi\sigma R_{0}\sum_{q}\frac{q^{2}\left|\rho_{q}\right|^{2}}{2R_{0}^{2}}. \end{array}</math></center> Finally,<center><math> \Delta F=F_{s}-F_{s}^{0}=2\pi\sigma R_{0}\sum_{q}\frac{\left|\rho_{q}\right|^{2}}{2R_{0}^{2}}\left(q^{2}R_{0}^{2}-1\right).</math></center> The conclusion is that modes having <math>q^{2}R_{0}^{2}\le1</math> will reduce the original cylinder free energy <math>F_{s}^{0}.</math> Hence, this is the onset of an instability called the Rayleigh instability of a liquid cylinder. A liquid cylinder will spontaneously start to develop undulations of wavelength <math>\lambda\sim q^{-1}\ge R_{0}</math>. These undulations will grow and eventually break up the cylinder into spherical droplets of size <math>R_{0}</math>. Note that if we go back to the planar surface by taking the limit <math>R_{0}\rightarrow\infty</math>, no such instability will occur since the planar geometry has the lowest surface area with respect to any other fluctuating surface.
