revision.comment: Adding {{WikiProject Languages}}
revision.text:
{{WikiProject Languages}}
== Fancy shmancy words ==
One thing that struck me while writing the Intermediate Grammar section is that this section introduces the distinction between morphology and syntax, but I don't think it should; after all the Beginner Sounds article doesn't mention the word "phonology". I propose that we remove the definition paragraph and attempt to re-target the sections as something like "Word Properties" and "Arranging Words" respectively. Anyone got any thoughts? [[User:Ingolemo|Ingolemo]] ([[User talk:Ingolemo|talk]]) 10:10, 27 May 2009 (UTC)
:Hm. Well, there is another side to the question. When I was going through these Beginner sections, and one of the things I was particularly doing was pruning technical terms, I pondered for some time over the word "morphology". (The word "syntax" didn't bother me; I think its technical meaning is pretty much in line with general usage.) Eventually I put together a case in favor of keeping "morphology/syntax" here, but didn't write it down at the time. As I recall, it went something like this:
:The word "morphology" comes in handy several times in this section; there does come a point of diminishing returns, at which eliminating the last few specialized words creates ambiguity and/or awkward verbosity and makes things ''harder'' for laymen to understand. It's a relatively painless term in itself; and it's one of the major taxon names of the subject (as opposed to narrow terms like "evidentiality" and "case"), making it potentially very helpful for a beginner to already know when approaching more advanced materials — as when trying to follow the gist of a more advanced discussion, or when tackling the spate of narrower technical terms in the Intermediate section.
:Having left "morphology" in place here, I also let stand the even gentler preview of the term that occurs in Beginner/Words, where it occurs exactly once, as the title of the first of two subsections (the second being "Vocabulary"). --[[User:Pi zero|Pi zero]] ([[User talk:Pi zero|talk]]) 14:11, 27 May 2009 (UTC)
::I see your point and having thought some more, I think I agree.
::However, I would like to note that when I asked five laymen friends to explain to me what they thought the word "syntax" meant, they were unable to do so. The best response I got was "it's something to do with grammar" but he was unable to elaborate further. Perhaps it would be prudent for us to get a person who is not familiar with the subject to read through it and determine whether the terms are acceptable? [[User:Ingolemo|Ingolemo]] ([[User talk:Ingolemo|talk]]) 21:21, 27 May 2009 (UTC)
::: A few thinking points. (These aren't meant to complicate the actual act of asking someone to look over the material and tell-me-what-you-think.) :::* It's not clear to me that the common usage status of "syntax" is necessarily a tipping point on this. We define both "morphology" and "syntax" here, and in effect by doing so we are also approximately defining "grammar"; so we're not actually relying much on the reader's prior knowledge of them. Big taxon names, all, and they're a matched set, too. :::* That leads into the potentially deep question of what level of knowledge we expect from the readers of this section. We ''do'' assume that the reader won't be uncomfortable with in-context use, without explicit definition, of terms like "subject", "object", and "auxiliary verb". I'm not actually proposing to open that can of worms, but it's something to keep in mind when choosing a lay test audience for the material, and certainly when interpreting the results of the test. :::* In having the material vetted by a layman, one really needs to think through carefully what kind of feedback to ask for. It would, for example, be pretty biasing to ask them to see if they thought the terminology was too technical. :::* High-quality victims, er, test subjects may not be easy to acquire in large numbers, and a given subject is really unfamiliar with the material only once. So one ought to be fairly selective about the version of the material that one spends such an opportunity on. ::: I can't say I'm really surprised to hear the reactions you got on the word "syntax"; it's not the first time I've found that parts of my idiolect are products of my atypical background. ::: BTW, the title you chose for this talk thread appears to be an instance of reduplication. --[[User:Pi zero|Pi zero]] ([[User talk:Pi zero|talk]]) 04:10, 28 May 2009 (UTC)
:::: I too do not think that "syntax" (or any other single word) is necessarily problematic. I was mostly just using it as an example to point out how we (with our particular biases) may not be the best people to evaluate it's usefulness to our target audience. You've already convinced me that, as things stand, there's no pressing need to simplify the vocabulary beyond it's current state. :::: I must admit that I'm in no position to actually do any testing. It's hard enough to get people IRL to be interested in my own conlanging, nevermind to go through the effort of critiquing a meta-article... :) [[User:Ingolemo|Ingolemo]] ([[User talk:Ingolemo|talk]]) 14:16, 28 May 2009 (UTC)
::::: The word "syntax" is a somewhat exceptional example, actually. My formal training is in computer science, rather than linguistics — but for trained computer scientists, "syntax" is what a parser analyzes. Modulo automated parsing, I should (ideally) be able to identify with non-linguists trying to break in to conlanging.
::::: But I too would be hard put to actually do any testing. [[User:Pi zero|Pi zero]] ([[User talk:Pi zero|talk]]) 21:39, 28 May 2009 (UTC)

page.title: Numerical Methods Qualification Exam Problems and Solutions (University of Maryland)/January 2005

revision.comment: /* Problem 1 */
revision.text:
== Problem 1 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Given <math>f \in C[a,b] \!\,</math>, let <math>p_n^* \!\,</math> denote the best uniform approximation to <math> f\!\,</math> among polynomials of degree <math>\leq n \!\,</math>, i.e.
:<math>\max_{x \in [a,b]} |f(x)-p_n(x)| \!\,</math>
is minimized by the choice <math>p_n=p_n^* \!\,</math>. Let <math>e(x)=f(x)-p_n^*(x) \!\,</math>. Prove that there are at least two points <math>x_1,x_2 \in [a,b] \!\,</math> such that
:<math>|e(x_1)|=|e(x_2)|=\max_{x\in[a,b]}|f(x)-p_n^*(x)| \!\,</math>
and <math>e(x_1)=-e(x_2) \!\,</math> |}
==Solution 1== Since both <math>f(x) \!\,</math> and <math>p_n^*(x) \!\,</math> are continuous, so is the function
:<math>e(x)=f(x)-p_n^*(x) \!\,</math>
and therefore <math>e(x) \!\,</math> attains both a maximum and a minimum on <math>[a,b] \!\,</math>.
Let <math>M=\max_{x \in [a,b]}e(x) \!\,</math> and <math>m=\min_{x \in [a,b]}e(x) \!\,</math>
If <math>M \neq -m \!\,</math>, then there exists a polynomial <math>q(x)=p_n^*(x)+\frac{M+m}{2} \!\,</math> (a vertical shift of the supposed best approximation <math>p_n^*(x)) \!\,</math> which is a better approximation to <math>f(x) \!\,</math>.
<math> \begin{align} f(x)-q(x) &= f(x)-p_n^*(x)-\frac{M+m}{2} \\ &\leq M-\frac{M+m}{2} \\ &= \frac{M-m}{2}\\ \\ \\ f(x)-q(x) &\geq m - \frac{M+m}{2}\\ &=\frac{m-M}{2} \end{align} \!\,</math>
Therefore,
<math>\|f(x)-q(x)\| \leq \frac{M-m}{2} \leq \|f-p_n^*\| = M \!\,</math>
Equality holds if and only if <math>m=-M \!\,</math>.
== Problem 2a== {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" | Find the node <math>x_1 \!\,</math> and the weight <math> w_1\!\,</math> so that the integration rule
<math>I=\int_0^1 x^{-\frac12}f(x) dx \approx w_1 f(x_1) \!\,</math>
is exact for linear functions. (No knowledge of orthogonal polynomials is required.)
|}
==Solution 2a== Let <math>f(x)=1 \!\,</math>. Then
<math>\int_0^1 \frac{1}{x^{\frac12}}=w_1 \cdot 1 \!\,</math>
which implies after computation
<math>w_1=2 \!\,</math>
Let <math>f(x)=x \!\,</math>. Then
<math>\int_0^1\frac{x}{x^{\frac12}}=w_1\cdot x_1 = 2 x_1 \!\,</math>
which implies after computation
<math>x_1=\frac13 \!\,</math>
== Problem 2b== {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Show that no one-point rule for approximating <math>I \!\,</math> can be exact for quadratics.
|}
==Solution 2b==
Suppose there is a one-point rule for approximating <math> I\!\,</math> that is exact for quadratics.
Let <math>f(x)=x^2 \!\,</math>.
Then,
<math>\int_0^1 \frac{x^2}{x^{\frac12}}= \frac25 \!\,</math>
but
<math>w_1x_1^2=2(\frac13)^2=\frac29 \!\,</math>,
a contradiction.
== Problem 2c== {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
In fact
<math>I-w_1f(x_1)=cf''(\xi) \mbox{ for some } \xi \in [0, 1]\!\,</math>
Find <math>c \!\,</math>. |}
==Solution 2c== Let <math>f(x)=x^2 \!\,</math>. Then <math>f''(x)=2 \!\,</math>
Using the values computed in part (b), we have
<math>\frac25-\frac29=c \cdot 2 \!\,</math>
which implies
<math>c=\frac{4}{45} \!\,</math>
== Problem 2d== {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Let <math>f(x) \!\,</math> and <math>g(x) \!\,</math> be two polynomials of degree <math>\leq 3 \!\,</math>. Suppose <math> f\!\,</math> and <math>g \!\,</math> agree at <math>x=a \!\,</math>, <math>x=b \!\,</math>, and <math>x=(a+b)/2 \!\,</math>. Show
<math>\int_a^b f(x) dx = \int_a^b g(x) dx \!\,</math> |}
==Solution 2d==
There exist <math>w_1,w_2,w_3 \!\,</math> such that if <math> f(x)\!\,</math> is a polynomial of degree <math>\leq 3 \!\,</math>
<math>\int_a^b f(x)dx= w_1f(a)+w_2f(b)+w_3f(\frac{a+b}{2}) \!\,</math>
Hence,
<math> \begin{align} \int_a^b f(x)dx &= w_1f(a)+w_2f(b)+w_3f(\frac{a+b}{2}) \\ &= w_1g(a)+w_2g(b)+w_3g(\frac{a+b}{2}) \\ &= \int_a^b g(x) dx \end{align} \!\,</math>
== Problem 3 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Let <math> A \in R^{n \times n} \!\,</math> be nonsingular and <math>b \in R^n \!\,</math>. Consider the following iteration for the solution <math>Ax=b \!\,</math>
<math>x_{k+1}=x_k+\alpha (b- Ax_k) \!\,</math> |}
==Problem 3a== {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Show that if all eigenvalues of <math>A \!\,</math> have positive real part then there will be some real <math>\alpha \!\,</math> such that the iterates converge for any starting vector <math>x_0 \!\,</math>. Discuss how to choose <math>\alpha \!\,</math> optimally in case <math>A \!\,</math> is symmetric and determine the rate of convergence.
|}
==Solution 3a==
===Convergence of any starting vector=== Using the iteration <math> \,\! x_{k+1}=x_k + \alpha(b-Ax_k)</math>, we have that
<math> \begin{align} e_{k+1} &= x_{k+1}-x^* \\ &= x_k - x^* + \alpha(b-Ax_k)\\ &= x_k - x^* + \alpha(Ax^*-Ax_k)\\ &= e_k - \alpha A e_k \\ &= (I-\alpha A)e_k \end{align} </math>
Then, computing norms we obtain
<math> \,\! \| e_{k+1}\| \leq \|I-\alpha A \| \| e_k\| </math>.
In particular, considering <math> \,\! \| \cdot \|_2 </math>, we have that
<math> \,\! \| e_{k+1}\|_2 \leq \|I-\alpha A \|_2 \| e_k\|_2 </math>.
Now, in order to study the convergence of the method, we need to analyze <math> \,\! \|I-\alpha A \|_2 </math>. We use the following characterization:
<math> \begin{align} \|I-\alpha A \|_2^2 &= \rho\left( (I-\alpha A) (I-\alpha A)^* \right) \\ &= \rho\left( I-\alpha A^*-\alpha A+ |\alpha|^2 AA^*\right) \end{align} </math>
Let's denote by <math> \,\! \lambda </math> an eigenvalue of the matrix <math> \,\! A </math>. Then <math> \rho\left( (I-\alpha A) (I-\alpha A)^* \right) < 1\,\! </math> implies
<math> 1-2\alpha Re(\lambda)+ \alpha^2 |\lambda|^2 < 1 \!\,</math>
i.e.
<math> -2\alpha Re(\lambda)+ \alpha^2 |\lambda|^2 < 0 \!\,</math>
The above equation is quadratic with respect to <math> \alpha\!\,</math> and opens upward. Hence using the quadratic formula we can find the roots of the equation to be
<math>\alpha_1=0 \quad \alpha_2= 2\frac{Re(\lambda)}{|\lambda|^2} \!\,</math>
Then, if <math> \,\! Re(\lambda)> 0 </math> for all the eigenvalues of the matrix <math> \,\! A </math>, we can find <math> \,\! \alpha \in (0,2\frac{Re(\lambda)}{|\lambda|^2}) </math> such that <math> \,\!\rho\left( (I-\alpha A) (I-\alpha A)^* \right) < 1 </math>, i.e., the method converges.
===Choosing alpha if A symmetric===
On the other hand, if the matrix <math> \,\! A </math> is symmetric, we have that <math> \,\! \|I-\alpha A \|_2 = \rho\left( I-\alpha A \right) </math>. Then using the Schur decomposition, we can find a unitary matrix <math> \,\! U </math> and a diagonal matrix <math> \,\! \Lambda </math> such that <math> \,\! A=U^*\Lambda U </math>, and in consequence,
<math> \begin{align}
\|I-\alpha A \|_2&=\|I-\alpha \Lambda \|_2 \\ &= \rho(I-\alpha \Lambda) \\ &= \max_{i=1,\dots,n}(1-\alpha \lambda_i) \\
\end{align} </math>
This last expression is minimized if <math> \,\! (1-\alpha \lambda_1)=-(1-\alpha \lambda_n) </math>, i.e, if <math> \,\! \alpha_{opt}=2/(\lambda_1+\lambda_n) </math>. With this optimal value of <math> \,\! \alpha </math>, we obtain that
<math> \,\! (I-\alpha_{opt} \Lambda)_{i,i}= 1-\frac{2}{\lambda_1+\lambda_n}\lambda_i, </math>
which implies that
<math> \,\! \| I-\alpha_{opt} \Lambda \|_2= \frac{\lambda_n-\lambda_1}{\lambda_1+\lambda_n} </math>.
Finally, we've obtained that
<math> \,\! \|e_{k+1}\|_2 \leq \frac{\lambda_n-\lambda_1}{\lambda_1+\lambda_n} \|e_{k} \|_2</math>.
==Problem 3b== {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Show that if some eigenvalues of <math>A \!\,</math> have negative real part and some have positive real part, then there is no real <math>\alpha \!\,</math> for which the iterations converge.
|}
==Solution 3b== If <math>Re(\lambda_i) >0 \!\,</math> for <math>i=1,2,\ldots,n \!\,</math>, then convergence occurs if
<math>\alpha \in (0, 2\frac{Re(\lambda)}{|\lambda|^2}) \!\,</math>
Hence <math>\alpha >0 \!\,</math>.
Similarly, if <math>Re(\lambda_i) <0 \!\,</math> for <math>i=1,2,\ldots,n \!\,</math>, then convergence occurs if
<math>\alpha \in (2\frac{Re(\lambda)}{|\lambda|^2},0) \!\,</math>
Hence <math>\alpha <0 \!\,</math>.
If some eigenvalues are positive and some negative, there does not exist a real <math>\alpha \!\,</math> for which the iterations converge since <math>\alpha \!\,</math> cannot be both positive and negative simultaneously.
==Problem 3c== {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Let <math>p=\|I-\alpha A\| < 1 \!\,</math> for a matrix norm associated to a vector norm. Show that the error can be expressed in terms of the difference between consecutive iterates, namely
:::::<math>\|x-x_{k+1}\| \leq \frac{\rho}{1-\rho} \|x_k-x_{k+1}\| \!\,</math>
(The proof of this is short but a little tricky)
|}
==Solution 3c== <math> \begin{align} \|x-x_{k+1}\| &\leq p\|x-x_{k+1}+x_{k+1}-x_k\| \\ &\leq p\|x-x_{k+1}\| + p \|x_{k+1}-x_k\| \\ (1-p)\|x-x_{k+1}\| &\leq p \|x_{k+1}-x_k\| \\ \|x-x_{k+1}\| &\leq \frac{p}{1-p} \|x_{k+1}-x_k\| \end{align} \!\,</math>
==Problem 3d== {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Let <math>A \!\,</math> be the tridiagonal matrix
:::::<math> \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 1 & 0 & 0 & \cdots & 0 \\ -1 & 3 & 1 & 0 & \cdots & 0 \\ \vdots & \ddots & \ddots & \ddots & \vdots & \vdots \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \ddots & \ddots & \vdots \\ \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & 3 & 1 \\ 0 & \cdots & \cdots & \cdots & -1 & 3 \end{pmatrix} \!\,</math>
Find a value of <math>\alpha \!\,</math> that guarantees convergence
|}
==Solution 3d==
By Gerschgorin's theorem, the magnitude of all the eigenvalues are between 1 and 5 i.e.
<math>1 < |\lambda| < 5 \!\,</math>
Therefore,
<math>\rho(I-\alpha A) = \max_i (|1-\alpha \lambda_i|) \leq |1 - \alpha 5 | \!\,</math>
We want
<math>\rho(I-\alpha A) < |1 -\alpha 5| < 1 \!\,</math>
Therefore,
<math>0 < \alpha < \frac25 \!\,</math>
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

page.title: Numerical Methods Qualification Exam Problems and Solutions (University of Maryland)/August 2004

revision.comment: /* Solution 1b */
revision.text:
== Problem 1 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
To compute <math>\sqrt{2} \!\,</math>, we consider the following Eudoxos iterations: starting with <math>x_0=y_0=1 \!\,</math>, we set <math>x_{n+1}=x_n+y_n \!\,</math> followed by <math>y_{n+1}=x_{n+1}+x_n \!\,</math>. Then <math>y_n / x_n \rightarrow \sqrt{2} \!\,</math> |}
== Problem 1a == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Explain the Eudoxos method in terms of the power method.
|}
== Solution 1a ==
The iteration can be represented in matrix formulation as follows:
<math> \begin{align} x_{n+1} &= x_n +y_n \\ y_{n+1} &= x_{n+1}+x_n = 2x_n + y_n \end{align} \!\,</math>
which can be written as
<math> \underbrace{ \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix} }_A \begin{bmatrix} x_n \\ y_n \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} x_{n+1} \\ y_{n+1} \end{bmatrix} \!\,</math>
Thus the iteration is just the power method since each step is represented by a multiplication by the matrix <math>A \!\,</math>.
The power method converges to the eigenvector of the largest eigenvalue.
The eigenvalues of <math>A \!\,</math> are computed to be <math>1 \pm \sqrt{2} \!\,</math>. Hence the largest eigenvalue is <math>1 + \sqrt{2} \!\,</math>
The corresponding eigenvector is then
<math> \begin{bmatrix} \sqrt{2} \\ 2 \end{bmatrix} \!\,</math>
Then <math>y_n / x_n \rightarrow \sqrt{2} \!\,</math> as desired.
== Problem 1b == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
How many iterations are required for an error <math>| y_n / x_n - \sqrt{2}| \leq 10^{-6} \!\,</math>
|}
== Solution 1b ==
Since convergence is linear, 7 steps is required to achieve the error bound.
== Problem 2 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Let <math>\{ p_n(x) \} \!\,</math> be a sequence of monic polynomials orthogonal on <math>[a,b] \!\,</math> with respect to the positive weight function <math>w(x) \!\,</math> ( <math>p_n \!\,</math> has degree <math>n \!\,</math>). Show that <math> p_n\!\,</math> satisfy a three term recursion formula of the form
<math>p_n(x)=(x-a_n)p_{n-1}(x)-b_n p_{n-2}(x) \!\,</math>
Give expressions for the coefficients <math>a_n \!\,</math> and <math>b_n \!\,</math>
|}
==Solution 2a==
First notice that <math>p_n - x p_{n-1} \in \Pi^{n-1} \!\,</math> and therefore we can express it as a linear combination of the monic polynomials of degree <math>n-1 \!\,</math> or less i.e.
<math>p_n - x p_{n-1}= -a_n p_{n-1}-b_n p_{n-2} + \sum_{i=0}^{n-3} \alpha_i p_i \qquad (*)\!\,</math>
Taking the inner product of both side of <math>(*) \!\,</math> with <math>p_{n-1} \!\,</math> yields from the orthogonality of the polynomials:
<math>-\langle x p_{n-1}, p_{n-1} \rangle = -a_n \langle p_{n-1}, p_{n-1} \rangle \!\,</math>
Rearranging terms then yields
<math>a_n = \frac{\langle xp_{n-1}, p_{n-1} \rangle}{ \langle p_{n-1}, p_{n-1} \rangle} \!\,</math>
Similarly, taking the inner product of both side of <math>(*) \!\,</math> with <math>p_{n-2} \!\,</math> yields from the orthogonality of the polynomials:
<math>b_n = \frac{\langle xp_{n-1}, p_{n-2} \rangle}{ \langle p_{n-2}, p_{n-2} \rangle} \!\,</math>
Notice that
<math> \begin{align} \langle xp_{n-1}, p_{n-2} \rangle &= \langle p_{n-1}, x p_{n-2} \rangle \\ &= \langle p_{n-1}, p_{n-1}+ \sum_{i=0}^{n-2} \alpha_i p_i \rangle \\ &= \langle p_{n-1}, p_{n-1} \rangle \end{align} \!\,</math>
Therefore,
<math>b_n = \frac{\langle p_{n-1}, p_{n-1} \rangle}{ \langle p_{n-2}, p_{n-2} \rangle} \!\,</math>
Finally, taking inner product of both side of <math>(*) \!\,</math> with <math> p_k, k=0,\ldots,n-3\!\,</math> yields,
<math>\alpha_k = - \frac{ \langle xp_{n-1}, p_k \rangle }{ \langle p_k, p_k \rangle} \!\,</math>
Notice that
<math> \langle xp_{n-1},p_k \rangle = \langle p_{n-1},\underbrace{x p_k}_{\in \Pi^{n-2}} \rangle = 0 \!\,</math>
which implies <math>\alpha_k=0 \!\,</math> for <math>k=0,1\ldots, n-3 \!\,</math>
== Problem 3a == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Find <math>\{p_0, p_1, p_2 \} \!\,</math> such that <math>p_i \!\,</math> is a polynomial of degree <math>i \!\,</math> and this set is orthogonal on <math>[0, \infty) \!\,</math> with respect to the weight function <math>w(x)=e^{-x} \!\,</math> |}
==Solution 3a==
Using Gram Schmidt with inner product defined as
<math>\langle f,g \rangle = \int_0^\infty w(x) fg dx \!\,</math>
and power basis <math>1,x,x^2 \!\,</math> as starting vectors, we get
<math>p_0=1 \!\,</math>
<math>p_1=x-1 \!\,</math>
<math>p_2=x^2-4x+2 \!\,</math>
== Problem 3b == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Find the weights and nodes of the 2 point Gaussian formula
<math>\int_0^\infty f(x) e^{-x}dx \approx w_1 f(x_1)+ w_2 f(x_2) \!\,</math>
Note: <math>\int_0^\infty x^n e^{-x}dx =n!, \quad 0!=1 \!\,</math> |}
== Solution 3b ==
Using test functions <math>f(x)=1 \!\,</math> and <math>f(x)=x \!\,</math> and using the roots of <math>p_2 \!\,</math> as nodes we find
<math>x_1 = 2 + \sqrt{2} \!\,</math>
<math>x_2 = 2 - \sqrt{2} \!\,</math>
<math>w_1 = \frac{2-\sqrt{2}}{4} \!\,</math>
<math>w_2 = \frac{2+\sqrt{2}}{4} \!\,</math>
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

page.title: Numerical Methods Qualification Exam Problems and Solutions (University of Maryland)/January 2004

revision.comment: /* Solution 2b */
revision.text:
== Problem 1 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Let <math>a=x_0< x_1<\cdots<x_n=b\!\,</math> be an arbitrary fixed partition of the interval <math>[a,b]\!\,</math>. A function <math>q(x)\!\,</math> is a quadratic spline function if
(i) <math>q \in C^1[a,b]\!\,</math>
(ii) On each subinterval <math>[x_i,x_{i+1}]\!\,</math>, <math>q\!\,</math> is a quadratic polynomial
The problem is to construct a quadratic spline <math>q(x)\!\,</math> interpolating data points <math>(x_0,y_0), (x_1,y_1),\ldots, (x_n,y_n)\!\,</math>. The construction is similar to the construction of the cubic spline but much easier.
|}
==Problem 1a== {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Show that if we know <math>z_i \equiv q'(x_i), i=0,\ldots,n\!\,</math>, we can construct <math>q\!\,</math>.
|}
==Solution 1a== Consider interval <math>[x_i,x_{i+1}]\!\,</math>. Since <math>q'_i(x)\!\,</math> is linear on this interval, using the point slope form we have
:<math>q_i'(x)=\frac{z_{i+1}-z_i}{x_{i+1}-x_i}(x-x_i)+z_i\!\,</math>
Integrating, we have
:<math>q_i(x)=z_ix+\frac{z_{i+1}-z_i}{x_{i+1}-x_i}\frac{(x-x_i)^2}{2}+K_i\!\,</math>
or, in a more convenient form,
:<math>q_i(x)=z_i(x-x_i)+\frac{z_{i+1}-z_i}{x_{i+1}-x_i}\frac{(x-x_i)^2}{2}+y_i\!\,</math>
==Problem 1b== {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Find equations which enable us to determine the <math>z_i\!\,</math>. You should find that one of the <math>z_i\!\,</math> can be prescribed arbitrarily, for instance <math>z_0=0\!\,</math>
|}
==Solution 1== Since <math>q\!\,</math> is continuous on <math>[a,b]\!\,</math>,
:<math>q_{i-1}(x_i)=q_i(x_i)=y_i\!\,</math>
i.e.
:<math>z_{i-1}(x_i-x_{i-1})+\frac{z_i-z_{i-1}}{x_i-x_{i-1}}\frac{(x_i-x_{i-1})^2}{2}+y_{i-1}=y_i\!\,</math>
Simplifying and rearranging terms yields the reoccurrence formula
:<math>z_i=-z_{i-1}+\frac{2(y_i-y_{i-1})}{x_i-x_{i-1}} \quad i=1,\ldots n\!\,</math>
== Problem 2a == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Give the definition of the <math>QR \!\,</math> algorithm for finding the eigenvalues of a matrix <math>A \!\,</math>. Define both the unshifted version and the version with shifts <math>\chi_0,\chi_1,\chi_2,\ldots \!\,</math> |}
== Solution 2a==
===Unshifted Version===
:<math>Q_kR_k=A_k \!\,</math> :<math>A_{k+1}=R_kQ_k \!\,</math>
===Shifted Version===
:<math>Q_kR_k=A_k-\chi_kI \!\,</math> :<math>A_{k+1}=R_kQ_k+\chi_kI \!\,</math>
== Problem 2b == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Show that in each case the matrices <math>A_1, A_2 \!\,</math> generated by the <math> QR\!\,</math> algorithm are unitarily equivalent to <math>A \!\,</math> (i.e. <math>A_i=U_iAU_i^H,U_i \!\,</math> unitary).
|}
==Solution 2b== Suppose <math>A_m=U^TAU</math> for some unitary <math>U</math>. Since <math>R_m=Q_m^TA_m</math> we have
<math>A_{m+1}=R_mQ_m=Q_m^TA_mQ_m=Q_m^TU^TAUQ_m</math>
which is as desired as <math>Q_mU</math> is unitary.
For the shifted case, the same argument holds using the fact that <math>R_m=Q_m^T(A_m-\chi_m I)</math>.
== Problem 2c == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Let
:<math>A=\begin{pmatrix} 3 & 1 \\ 1 & 2 \end{pmatrix} \!\,</math>
Use plane rotations (Givens rotations) to carry out one step of the <math>QR \!\,</math> algorithm on <math>A \!\,</math>, first without shifting and then using the shift <math> \chi_0=1\!\,</math>. Which seems to do better? The eigenvalues of <math>A \!\,</math> are <math>\lambda_1=1.382,\lambda_2=3.618 \!\,</math>. (Recall that a plane rotation is a matrix of the form
:<math>Q=\begin{pmatrix} c & -s \\ s & c \end{pmatrix} \!\,</math>
with <math>c^2+s^2=1 \!\,</math> |}
==Solution 2c==
The shifted iteration appears to work better because its diagonal entries are closer to the actual eigenvalues than the diagonal entries of the unshifted iteration.
===Unshifted Iteration===
<math>A_1=\begin{pmatrix} 3.5 & .5 \\ .5 & 1.5 \end{pmatrix} \!\,</math>
===Shifted Iteration===
<math>A_1=\begin{pmatrix} 3.6 & .2 \\ .2 & 1.4 \end{pmatrix} \!\,</math>
== Problem 3 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Let <math>A \!\,</math> be an <math>N \times N \!\,</math> symmetric, positive definite matrix. Then we know that solving <math>Ax=b \!\,</math> is equivalent to minimizing the functional <math>F(x)=\frac12 \langle x, Ax \rangle - \langle b, x \rangle \!\,</math> where <math>\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle \!\,</math> denotes the standard inner product in <math>R^N \!\,</math>. To solve the problem by minimization of <math>F \!\,</math> we consider the general iterative method <math>x_{v+1}=x_v+\alpha_vd_v \!\,</math>
|}
== Problem 3a == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
When <math>x_v \!\,</math> and <math>d_v \!\,</math> are given, show that the value of <math>\alpha_v \!\,</math> which minimizes <math>F(x_v+\alpha d_v) \!\,</math> as a function of <math>\alpha \!\,</math> is given in terms of the residual <math> r_v\!\,</math>
:<math>\alpha_v=\frac{\langle r_v, d_v \rangle}{\langle d_v, Ad_v \rangle}, \quad r_v=b-Ax_v \!\,</math>
|}
== Solution 3a ==
===Useful Relationship===
Since <math>A \!\,</math> is symmetric
:<math>(Ax,y)=(x,A^Ty)=(x,Ay) \!\,</math>
This relationship will used throughout the solutions.
===Substitute into Functional===
<math> \begin{align} F(x_v+\alpha d_v) &= \frac12\langle x_v+\alpha d_v, Ax_v+\alpha A d_v \rangle - \langle b, x_v + \alpha d_v \rangle \\ &= \frac{\langle d_v,Ad_v \rangle}{2}\alpha^2+\alpha \langle d_v,Ax_v \rangle - \alpha \langle b, d_v \rangle + \frac12 \langle x_v, A x_v \rangle - \langle b, x_v \rangle \end{align} \!\,</math>
===Take Derivative With Respect to Alpha===
<math>F'(x_v+\alpha d_v)=\langle d_v, Ad_v \rangle \alpha + \langle d_v, Ax_v \rangle - \langle b, d_v \rangle \!\,</math>
===Set Derivative Equal To Zero===
<math>0=\langle d_v, Ad_v \rangle \alpha + \langle d_v, Ax_v -b \rangle \!\,</math>
which implies
<math>\alpha = \frac{\langle d_v, r_v \rangle}{\langle d_v, A d_v \rangle} \!\,</math>
== Problem 3b == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Let <math>\{d_j\}_{j=1}^N \!\,</math> be an <math>A \!\,</math>-orthogonal basis of <math>R^N \!\,</math>, <math>\langle d_j, Ad_k \rangle=0, j\neq k \!\,</math>. Consider the expansion of the solution <math>x \!\,</math> in this basis:
:<math>x=\sum_{j=1}^N \hat{x_j}d_j \!\,</math>
Use that <math>A-\!\,</math>orthogonality of the <math>d_j \!\,</math> to compute the <math>\hat{x}_j \!\,</math> in terms of the solution <math>x \!\,</math> and the <math> d_j\!\,</math>'s
|}
== Solution 3b ==
<math> \begin{align} \langle x, Ad_k \rangle &= \langle \sum_{j=1}^n \hat{x}_j d_j, A d_k \rangle \\ &= \sum_{j=1}^N \hat{x}_j \langle d_j, A d_k \rangle\\ &= \hat{x}_k \langle d_k, Ad_k \rangle \end{align} \!\,</math>
which implies
<math>\hat{x}_k = \frac{\langle x, Ad_k \rangle}{ \langle d_k, A d_k \rangle} \!\,</math>
== Problem 3c == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Let <math>x_v \!\,</math> denote the partial sum
:<math>x_v = \sum_{j=1}^{v-1}\hat{x}_j d_j, \quad v=2,3,\ldots \!\,</math>
so that <math>x_{v+1}=x_v+\hat{x}_v d_v \!\,</math> where the <math>\hat{x}_v \!\,</math>'s are the coefficients found in (b). Use the fact that <math>x_v \in \mbox{span}\{d_1,d_2,\ldots,d_{v-1}\} \!\,</math> and the <math>A\!\,</math>-orthogonality of the <math>d_j \!\,</math>'s to conclude that the coefficient <math>\hat{x}_v \!\,</math> is given by the optimal <math>\alpha_v \!\,</math> i.e.
:<math>\hat{x}_v=\frac{\langle r_v, d_v \rangle}{\langle d_v, Ad_v \rangle}=\alpha_v \!\,</math> |}
== Solution 3c ==
<math> \begin{align} \langle r_v, d_v \rangle &= \langle b-Ax_v, d_v \rangle \\ &= \langle Ax-Ax_v, dv \rangle \\ &= \langle Ax, d_v \rangle - \langle Ax_v, d_v \rangle \\ &= \langle x,A d_v \rangle - \underbrace{\langle x_v, A d_v \rangle}_0 \\ &=\hat{x}_v \langle d_v, Ad_v \rangle \end{align} \!\,</math>
which implies
<math>\hat{x}_v=\frac{\langle r_v, d_v \rangle}{\langle d_v, Ad_v \rangle} \!\,</math>
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

page.title: Numerical Methods Qualification Exam Problems and Solutions (University of Maryland)/August 2003

revision.comment: /* Solution 3 */
revision.text:
== Problem 1 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
|}
==Solution 1==
== Problem 2 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
|}
==Solution 2==
== Problem 3 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Let <math>A,B \in R^{n \times n} \!\,</math> be symmetric and positive definite matrices, and let <math>b \in R^n \!\,</math>. Consider the quadratic function <math> Q(x)=\frac12 x^T Ax - x^Tb \!\,</math> for <math>x \in R^n \!\,</math> and a descent method to approximate the solution of <math>Ax=b \!\,</math>:
<math>x_{k+1}=x_k + \alpha_k d_k \!\,</math> |}
== Problem 3a == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Define the concept of steepest descent <math>d_k \!\,</math> and show how to compute the optimal stepsize <math>\alpha_k \!\,</math>
|}
===Descent Direction===
<math>\nabla Q(x_k) \cdot d_k < 0 \!\,</math>
===Optimal step size ===
Choose <math>\alpha_k \!\,</math> such that <math>Q(x_k+\alpha_k d_k) \!\,</math> is minimized i.e.
<math>\alpha_k : \min_{\alpha_k} Q(x_k+\alpha_k d_k) \!\,</math>
<math> Q(x_k+\alpha_kd_k) = \langle x_k + \alpha_k d_k, Ax_k + \alpha_k A d_k \rangle - \langle x_k + \alpha_k d_k, b \rangle \!\,</math>
<math>\frac{d}{d \alpha} Q(x_k+\alpha_k d_k)= \langle A d_k, x_k \rangle + \alpha_k \langle A d_k, d_k \rangle - \langle d_k , b \rangle \!\,</math>
Setting the above expression equal to zero gives the optimal <math>\alpha_k \!\,</math>:
<math>\alpha_k = \frac{\langle d_k, b-Ax_k \rangle}{\langle A d_k, d_k \rangle} \!\,</math>
Note that since <math>A \!\,</math> is symmetric
<math>\langle d_k, A x_k \rangle = \langle A d_k, x_k \rangle \!\,</math>
== Problem 3b == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Formulate the steepest descent (or gradient method) method and write a pseudocode which implements it.
|}
== Solution 3b==
Note that <math>d_k = -\nabla Q(x_k) = b - Ax_k = r_k \!\,</math>. Then the minimal <math>\alpha_k \!\,</math> is given by <math>\frac{\langle r_k, r_k \rangle }{\langle r_k, r_k \rangle_A} \!\,</math>
Given <math>x_0 \in R^n \!\,</math> For <math> k=0,1,2,\ldots \!\,</math> <math> \begin{align} r_k &= b- Ax_k \\ &\mbox{If } r_k =0, \mbox { then quit } \\ d_k &= r_k \\ \alpha_k &= \frac{\langle r_k, r_k \rangle }{\langle r_k, r_k \rangle_A} \\ x_{k+1}&=x_k + \alpha_k d_k \end{align} </math>
== Problem 3c == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Let <math>B^{-1} \!\,</math> be a preconditioner of <math>A \!\,</math>. Show how to modify the steepest descent method to work for <math>B^{-1}Ax=B^{-1}b \!\,</math> and write a pseudocode. Note that <math>B^{-1}A \!\,</math> may not be symmetric. (Hint: proceed as with the conjugate gradient method). |}
==Solution 3==
Since <math> B \!\,</math> is symmetric, positive definite, <math>B=E^TE \!\,</math> where <math>E \!\,</math> is upper triangular (Cholesky Factorization).
Then <math>B^{-1}=E^{-1}E^{-T} \!\,</math>
Hence,
<math> \begin{align} B^{-1} Ax & = B^{-1}b \\ E^{-1}E^{-T} Ax &= E^{-1}E^{-T} b \\ E^{-T} Ax &=E^{-T}b \\ \underbrace{E^{-T}A E^{-1}}_{\tilde{A}} \underbrace{ Ex}_{\tilde{x}} &= \underbrace{E^{-T}b}_{\tilde{b}} \end{align} \!\,</math>
<math>\tilde{A} \!\,</math> is symmetric:
<math>(E^{-T}AE^{-1})^T=E^{-T}A E^{-1} \!\,</math> since <math>A \!\,</math> symmetric
<math>\tilde{A} \!\,</math> is positive definite:
<math>x^TE^{-T}AE^{-1}x= (E^{-1}x)^T A(E^{-1}x) > 0 \!\,</math> since <math>A \!\,</math> positive definite
===Pseudocode===
Given <math>x_0 \in R^n \!\,</math> For <math> k=0,1,2,\ldots \!\,</math> <math> \begin{align} \tilde{x_k} &= E x_k \\ r_k &= \tilde{b}- \tilde{A} \tilde{x_k} \\ &\mbox{If } r_k =0, \mbox { then quit } \\ d_k &= r_k \\ \alpha_k &= \frac{\langle r_k, r_k \rangle }{\langle r_k, r_k \rangle_{\tilde{A}}} \\ x_{k+1}&=x_k + \alpha_k d_k \end{align} </math>

revision.comment: /* Solution 2 */
revision.text:
== Problem 1 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
|}
==Solution 1==
== Problem 2 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Suppose there is a quadrature formula
<math>\int_a^b f(x)dx \approx w_af(a)+w_bf(b)+\sum_{j=1}^n w_j f(x_j) \!\, </math>
which produces the exact integral whenever <math>f \!\, </math> is a polynomial of degree <math>2n+1 \!\, </math>. Here the nodes <math>\{ x_j \}_{j=1}^n \!\, </math> are all distinct. Prove that the nodes lies in the open interval <math>(a,b) \!\, </math> and the weights <math>w_a, w_b \!\, </math> and <math>\{w_j\}_{j=1}^n \!\, </math> are positive.
|}
==Solution 2==
===All nodes lies in (a,b)===
Let <math> \{x_i\}_{i=1}^l \!\, </math> be the nodes that lie in the interval <math>(a,b) \!\, </math>.
Let <math>q_l(x)=\prod_{i=1}^l(x-x_i) \!\, </math> which is a polynomial of degree <math> l\!\, </math>.
Let <math>p_n(x)=\prod_{i=1}^n(x-x_i)=q_l(x)\prod_{i=1}^{n-l}(x-x_i) \!\, </math> which is a polynomial of degree <math>n >l \!\, </math>.
Then
<math> \langle p_n, q_l \rangle = \int_a^b q_l^2(x) \underbrace{\prod_{i=1}^{n-l}(x-x_i)}_{r(x)} \neq 0 \!\, </math>
since <math>r(x) \!\, </math> is of one sign in the interval <math>(a,b) \!\, </math> since for <math>i=1,2,\ldots n -l \!\, </math>, <math>x_i \not \in (a,b).\!\, </math>
This implies <math>q_l \!\, </math> is of degree <math>n \!\, </math> since otherwise
<math>\langle p_n, q_l \rangle = 0\!\, </math>
from the orthogonality of <math>p_n \!\, </math>. ===All weights positive===
== Problem 3 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
|}
==Solution 3==

page.title: Numerical Methods Qualification Exam Problems and Solutions (University of Maryland)/Aug06 667

revision.comment: /* Solution 4a */
revision.text:
== Problem 4 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Suppose that <math>f: R \rightarrow R \!\,</math> is smooth and that the boundary value problem
<math>u''=f(u) \mbox{ on } (0,1), \quad u(0)=(1)=0 \!\,</math>
has unique solution. |}
== Problem 4a == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
For <math>N \in \mathbb{N} \!\,</math>, let <math>x_i=\frac{1}{N},i=0,\ldots,N \!\,</math>. Write down a system of <math>N+1 \!\,</math> equations to obtain an approximation <math>u_i \!\,</math> for the solution <math>u \!\,</math> at <math>x_i \!\,</math> by replacing the second derivatives by a symmetric difference quotient.
|}
== Solution 4a==
The symmetric difference quotient is given by
<math>\frac{u(x+h)-2u(x)+u(x-h)}{h^2}=u''(x) \!\,</math>
Hence we have the following system equations that incorporates the initial conditions <math>u(0)=u(1)=0 \!\,</math>.
<math> \underbrace{ \frac{1}{h^2} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & & & & & & \\ 1 & -2 & 1 & & & & \\ & 1 & -2 & 1 & & & \\ & & \ddots & \ddots & \ddots & & \\ & & & & 1 & -2 & 1 \\ & & & & & & 1 \end{bmatrix} }_{A} \underbrace{ \begin{bmatrix} u_0 \\ u_1 \\ u_2 \\ \vdots \\ \vdots \\ u_n \end{bmatrix} }_{U} = \underbrace{ \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ f(u_1) \\ f(u_2) \\ \vdots\\ f(u_{n-1})\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} }_{f} \!\,</math>
== Problem 4b == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Write the system of equations in the form <math>F(U)=0 \!\,</math>. Define domain and range of <math>F \!\,</math> and explain the meaning of the variable <math>U \!\,</math>.
|}
== Solution 4b==
<math> \underbrace{AU-f}_{F(U)}=0\!\,</math>
Domain: <math> R^{N+1} \!\,</math>
Range: <math> R^{N+1} \!\,</math>
<math>U \!\,</math> is a vector containing <math>N+1 \!\,</math> approximations <math>u_i \!\,</math> for the solution <math>u \!\,</math> at <math>x_i \!\,</math>
==Problem 4c== {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Formulate Newton's method for the solution of the system in (b) with <math>U^{(0)}=0 \!\,</math>. Give explicit expressions for all objects involved (as far as this is reasonable). Determine a sufficient condition that ensures that the iterates <math>U^{(k)} \!\,</math> in the Newton scheme are defined. Without doing any further calculations, can you decide whether the sequence <math>U^{(k)} \!\,</math> converges. Why or why not?
|} ==Solution 4c ==
===Newton's Method===
<math>U^{k+1}=U^{k}-J(F(U^{(k)})^{-1}F(U^{(k)}) \!\,</math>
where <math>J(A) \!\,</math> denotes the Jacobian of a matrix <math>A\!\,</math>.
Specifically,
<math>J(F(U^{(k)})=J(AU-F)=A-J(F) \!\,</math>
===Sufficient Condition===
If <math>J(F(U^{(k)})^{-1} \!\,</math> exists, then <math>U^{(k)} \!\,</math> iterates are defined.
===Convergence of sequnce===
We cannot decide if the sequence converges since Newton's method only guarantees local convergence.
In general, for local convergence of Newton's method we need:
* <math>F \!\,</math> differentriable
* <math>D(F(U^*)) \!\,</math> invertible
* <math>D(F) \!\,</math> Lipschitz
* <math>U^{(0)} \!\,</math> close to solution <math>U^* \!\,</math>
== Problem 5 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Consider the boundary value problem
:<math>-u''=f, \quad 0<x<1 \!\,</math>
with boundary conditions <math>u(0)=0 \!\,</math> and <math>u'(1)+\alpha u(1)=0 \!\,</math>. Here <math>\alpha \!\,</math> is a given positive number. |}
== Problem 5a == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Describe a Galerkin method to solve this problem using piecewise linear functions with respect to a uniform mesh.
|}
===Weak Formulation=== Find <math>u \in U=\{u \in H^1 : u(0)=0 \} \!\,</math> such that for all <math> v \in U\!\,</math>
<math>\int_0^1 -u''v=\int_0^1 fv \!\,</math>
which after integrating by parts and plugging in initial conditions we have
<math>\int_0^1 u'v'= \int_0^1 fv - \alpha u(1)v(1) \!\,</math>
Let <math>\{x_i\}_{i=0}^{N+1} \!\,</math> be the nodes of a uniform partition of <math> [0,1]\!\,</math> where <math>x_0=0 \!\,</math> and <math>x_i=ih \!\,</math>.
Let <math>\{\phi_i \}_{i=0}^{N+1} \!\,</math> be the standard "hat" functions defined as follows:
For <math>i=1,2\ldots,N \!\,</math>
<math>\phi_i = \begin{cases} \frac{x-x_{i-1}}{h} & \mbox{ for } x \in [x_{i-1}, x_i] \\ \frac{x_{i+1}-x}{h} & \mbox{ for } x \in [x_i, x_{i+1}] \\ 0 & \mbox{ otherwise } \end{cases} \!\,</math>
<math> \phi_{N+1}= \begin{cases} \frac{x-x_N}{h} & \mbox{ for } x \in [x_N, x_{N+1}] \\ 0 & \mbox{ otherwise } \end{cases} </math>
Also <math>\phi_0=0 \!\,</math> since <math>u(0)=0 \!\,</math>
Then <math>\{ \phi_i \}_{i=0}^{N+1} \!\,</math> forms a basis for the discrete space <math>U_h=\{ u \in H^1[0,1] : u(0)=0, u \mbox{ piecewise linear } \} \!\,</math>
== Problem 5b == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Derive the matrix equations for this Galerkin method. Write out explicitly that equation of the linear system which involves <math>\alpha \!\,</math>
|}
===Discrete Weak Formulation===
Find <math>u_h \in U_h \!\,</math> such that for all <math>v \in U_h \!\,</math>
<math>\int_0^1 u_h' v_h' = \int_0^1 f v_h - \alpha u(1) v(1) \!\,</math>
Since <math>\{ \phi_i \}_{i=0}^{N+1} \!\,</math> forms a basis, we have
<math>u_h = \sum_{i=0}^{N+1}u_{hi}\phi_i \!\,</math>
Also for <math>j=1,\ldots,N+1 \!\,</math>
<math>\sum_{i=0}^{N+1}u_{hi} \int_0^1 \phi_i' \phi_j' = \int_0^1 f \phi_j + \alpha \sum_{i=0}^{N+1} u_{hi} \phi_i(1) \phi_j (1) \!\,</math>
In matrix form
<math> \begin{bmatrix} \frac{2}{h} & -\frac{1}{h} & & && \\ -\frac{1}{h} & \frac{2}{h} &-\frac{1}{h} & && \\ & \ddots & \ddots & \ddots && \\ & & & &-\frac{1}{h} & \frac{2}{h}+\alpha \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} u_{h_1}\\ u_{h_2}\\ \vdots\\ u_{h_{N+1}} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \int_0^1 f \phi_1 \\ \int_0^1 f \phi_2 \\ \vdots \\ \int_0^1 f\phi_{N+1} \end{bmatrix}
\!\,</math>
== Problem 6 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Consider the linear multistep method
<math> y_{n+1}=\frac43 y_n - \frac13 y_{n-1}+\frac23 h f(x_{n+1},y_{n+1})\!\,</math>
for the solution of the initial value problem <math>y'(x)=f(x,y(x)),y(0)=y_0 \!\,</math> |}
== Problem 6a == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Show that the truncation error is of order 2. |}
== Problem 6b == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
State the condition for consistency of a linear multistep method and verify it for the scheme in this problem.
|}
== Solution 6b == <math> \begin{align} y_{n+1} &=\sum_{j=0}^p a_j y_{n-j}+h\sum_{j=-1}^p b_j f(t_{n-j},y_{n-j}) \\ &=a_0y_n +a_1 y_{n-1}+\ldots+a_py_{n-p}+h [b_{-1}f(t_{n+1},y_{n+1})+b_0f(t_{n},y_n)+b_1f(t_{n-1},y_{n-1})+\ldots+b_pf(t_{n-p},y_{n-p})]
\end{align} \!\,</math>
Conditions:
(i) <math>\sum_{j=0}^p a_j=1 \!\,</math>
<math>\frac43 + -\frac{1}{3}=1 \!\,</math>
(ii)<math>\sum_{j=-1}^p b_j- \sum_{j=0}^p j a_j = 1\!\,</math>
<math>\frac23 - (0 \cdot \frac 43 + 1 \cdot -\frac13) = 1 \!\,</math>
== Problem 6c == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Does the scheme satisfy the root condition and or the strong root condition?
|}
The scheme satisfies the root condition but not the strong root condition since the roots are given by
<math>\lambda=\frac{\frac43 \pm \sqrt{\frac{16}{9}-\frac43} }{2} \!\,</math>
which implies <math>\lambda_1 =1 \!\,</math> and <math>\lambda_2=\frac13 \!\,</math>
{{BookCat}}
